clinical_study.brief_title: Ultrasound Predictors of Difficult Spinal Anesthesia
clinical_study.official_title: The Use of Ultrasound to Predict a Difficult Spinal Anesthesia: a Prospective Single-blind Observational Study

brief_summary.textblock: This prospective observational study aims to investigate about the efficacy of spine ultrasound in predicting difficult spinal anesthesia

primary_outcome.description: Ultrasound visibility of Dura Mater complexes on the intervertebral space chosen for spinal anesthesia

Difficult spinal anesthesia includes: failure, procedure lasting more than 400 seconds from the insertion of the needle to the deliquoration; a number of needle replacements greater than 10; a change of the clinician practicing spinal anesthesia.

secondary_outcome.description: Spinal anesthesia duration (expressed in seconds) from the insertion of the needle to the deliquoration

intervention.description: Spinal Ultrasound is performed by an observer who records ultrasound characteristics of the intervertebral space chosen by the anesthetist who will practice spinal anesthesia

Spinal anesthesia is performed by an anesthetist after the observer recorded ultrasound characteristics of the intervertebral space chosen by the anesthetist, who is blinded to the ultrasound evaluation.

study_pop.textblock: Patients undergoing spinal anesthesia for elective orthopedic and urologic surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients undergoing spinal anesthesia for elective surgery
- ASA physical status score < 4
Exclusion Criteria:
- Contraindications to regional anesthesia
- ASA physical status score ≥ 4
- Patient's refusal or inability to sing the informed consent
- Previous spine surgery affecting the intervertebral space chosen for spinal anesthesia
